title: Das Experiment
descriptions:
Das Experiment is a German psychological thriller loosely inspired by the Stanford prison experiment. Set in contemporary Germany, it follows Tarek Fahd, a cash-strapped former taxi driver and journalist who sees an ad seeking volunteers for a two-week study on prison life. Motivated by the payout and the chance for a story, he signs up with the hidden intention of secretly recording the experience to sell an exposé. Along with other volunteers, he is assigned at random to either “guard” or “prisoner.” Tarek becomes Prisoner 77; a quiet, intense volunteer named Berus becomes one of the guards.

The experiment begins in a controlled environment constructed inside a research facility. The supervising scientists, led by Professor Thon, instruct the group on strict rules: guards manage the prisoners, who must obey; no violence; the experiment can be ended if safety is compromised. Initially, the setup appears benign, even artificial. The guards receive uniforms, sunglasses, and batons; the prisoners are stripped of personal identity, given smocks and numbers, and deprived of dignity in subtle ways. The depersonalization starts to shape behavior. Some guards try to follow the rules humanely, while others, particularly Berus, quickly embrace their newfound authority.

Tarek, skeptical of the setup, begins to provoke small confrontations to test the boundaries and secure a compelling story. He resists orders, jokes, and encourages solidarity among prisoners. These acts, though minor at first, threaten the guards’ control. Berus interprets the defiance as a challenge to the order and escalates discipline, imposing humiliations—making prisoners perform degrading tasks, depriving them of basic comforts, and enforcing arbitrary punishments. The power imbalance rapidly grows.

Inside the control room, Thon and his team monitor the interactions via cameras and biometric sensors. Initially they are fascinated as the data supports their hypotheses about role conformity and authority. As tensions rise, the scientists debate intervention but hesitate, hoping to observe how dynamics evolve. This reluctance becomes a key moral failure as the situation spirals.

Among the prisoners, alliances and fractures appear. Tarek’s leadership inspires some but draws ire from others who fear reprisals. A timid prisoner suffers psychological stress; another tries to keep his head down to survive. The guards coalesce around Berus, who pushes the limits, testing how far they can go without official censure. When Tarek continues to resist—refusing to use his number, standing up for fellow inmates—Berus targets him. The guards subject Tarek to humiliations and solitary confinement, but he remains defiant, looking for ways to expose the experiment’s abuses.

The guard unit’s internal dynamics sour as well. A few still care about the rules and the experiment’s integrity, but peer pressure and the rush of authority push them to complicity. Berus’ chilling calm and assertiveness create a groupthink where dissent is risky. He frames every act of resistance as a threat that must be crushed. The guards devise manipulative tactics: sleep deprivation, stress positions, and public punishments. The boundary between simulation and reality dissolves.

Tarek manages to pass information and maintain contact with some prisoners, attempting to orchestrate a plan to regain control or attract outside attention. Meanwhile, his relationship with Dora, a woman he met just before the experiment, adds a tether to the outside world and raises the stakes: he wants to survive, but also to reveal the truth. As the scientists’ oversight falters, Dora grows concerned and seeks answers, showing how opaque the supposedly controlled study has become.

After a staged infraction escalates, violence erupts. A vulnerable prisoner is pushed beyond his limits, leading to a breakdown that shocks even some guards. Thon, recognizing the danger, finally tries to shut down the experiment. But the chain of command has frayed; the guards, led by Berus, are invested in maintaining domination and resist directives, interpreting them as more “tests.” The cameras and locks, once tools of oversight, become instruments of entrapment.

The facility descends into chaos. Prisoners seize moments of opportunity, and Tarek leads a desperate attempt to disable surveillance and escape captivity. The guards respond with brutal force. The conflict spills into hallways and maintenance areas, turning the sterile lab setting into a battleground. Tarek confronts Berus in a charged showdown that lays bare the core themes: how quickly ordinary people can embrace cruelty when granted power, and how systems can enable that cruelty through passivity.

In the aftermath, the experiment collapses. Death and injury shatter the pretense that it was a controlled study. Outside authorities are finally alerted; the institution’s failures are exposed. Tarek survives, scarred but determined to reveal what happened. The scientists face culpability for their negligence, and the participants grapple with the horrifying extremes they reached under the experiment’s conditions.

Das Experiment ends as a stark commentary on authority, identity, and moral responsibility. By stripping participants
